update.description:
~~Depends on pull request #200 and pull request #201. Please review them first~~

Adds ogre1.x and ogre2.x implementation of a thermal camera.

The data output is an image of single channel 16 bit temperature values. Typical thermal sensors produces data in 10mK or 100mK resolutions and this behavior can be configured by setting the thermal camera’s LinearResolution.

e.g. for LinearResolution of 0.01 \(10mK\), the max temperature data generated is:

65535 \* 0.01 = 655.35 Kelvin / 680.72 F / 360.4 C

Another example is the FLIR Lepton camera which outputs 14 bit data, which can be simulated by setting LinearResolution to 0.04.

The temperature of a Visual can be set using `Visual::SetUserData` function introduced in pull request #200 with the key `temperature`, and the environment temperature is set using `TheramlCamera::SetAmbientTemperature`

‌

Update [70b4a9b](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/commits/70b4a9b65a06fed9e64e2a7bffcc360192a31897): Added function to set temperature variation for heat sources \(instead of using a hard coded value\).  If not set, uniform temperature is assumed for the entire body of the heat source.
update.title: Add ThermalCamera

content.raw: thanks for the info! I didn’t know about unique global symbols. I did a quick grep using `nm` on the libOgre\*.so libraries to look for unique global symbols \(type `u` according to this [page](https://sourceware.org/binutils/docs/binutils/nm.html)\) and found that one of its plugins has these symbols. The symbols don’t belong to a singleton class which is what the crash msg is complaining about so I’m not sure if that plugin is the problem. I’ll investigate a bit more.
content.html: thanks for the info! I didn’t know about unique global symbols. I did a quick grep using nm on the libOgre*.so libraries to look for unique global symbols (type u according to this page) and found that one of its plugins has these symbols. The symbols don’t belong to a singleton class which is what the crash msg is complaining about so I’m not sure if that plugin is the problem. I’ll investigate a bit more.

content.raw: I wouldn’t rule out the possibility that we can do something with symbol visibility to avoid clashes, but I haven’t had time to investigate that \(and I don’t really know enough about linkers to judge whether such a solution is likely to help\).
content.html: I wouldn’t rule out the possibility that we can do something with symbol visibility to avoid clashes, but I haven’t had time to investigate that (and I don’t really know enough about linkers to judge whether such a solution is likely to help).

content.raw:
Yeah, fundamentally the decision to load or unload a dynamically linked library falls on the operating system. The most we can do from user space is tell the operating system “I wouldn’t mind if you went ahead and unloaded that library now”, but we can’t force it to happen because the operating system might decide that the library is still needed for reasons that aren’t obvious to us.

One example I know of off the top of my head is the gcc linker will sometimes put a “unique global symbol” into a library \(this usually happens when dealing with global variables that have external linkage\). Whenever a shared library has even one “unique global symbol”, the operating system will never unload that shared library from a process until the process is terminated. I won’t pretend to know exactly what the motive/justification is for that behavior, but it’s something that I’ve noticed in testing. So if the Ogre library was compiled with any “unique global symbols” then the operating system will never unload it.
content.html:
Yeah, fundamentally the decision to load or unload a dynamically linked library falls on the operating system. The most we can do from user space is tell the operating system “I wouldn’t mind if you went ahead and unloaded that library now”, but we can’t force it to happen because the operating system might decide that the library is still needed for reasons that aren’t obvious to us.

One example I know of off the top of my head is the gcc linker will sometimes put a “unique global symbol” into a library (this usually happens when dealing with global variables that have external linkage). Whenever a shared library has even one “unique global symbol”, the operating system will never unload that shared library from a process until the process is terminated. I won’t pretend to know exactly what the motive/justification is for that behavior, but it’s something that I’ve noticed in testing. So if the Ogre library was compiled with any “unique global symbols” then the operating system will never unload it.

content.raw: I see :disappointed: It would be good to at least shortcut before hitting the assertion until we're able to unload the libs
content.html: I see It would be good to at least shortcut before hitting the assertion until we're able to unload the libs

content.raw: hmm they can. I’ll think about this design a little more and keep it `protected` for now so it's consistent with other classes.
content.html: hmm they can. I’ll think about this design a little more and keep it protected for now so it's consistent with other classes.

content.raw: yeah I looked into this a while back. The only way I could think of for avoiding symbol collisions is to unload one engine first before loading the next one. However, my attempts of using ign-plugin’s [ForgetLibrary\*](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-plugin/src/8f724376b94bf6e298a7d66a37e5e5a68a329409/loader/include/ignition/plugin/Loader.hh#lines-210) functions to unload a plugin have been unsuccessful. It’s also mentioned in the function’s description that the unload operation is not guaranteed to succeed. I remember asking @{557058:67759e29-d1df-465f-868d-047738e36fc9}  about this before. So I’m out of ideas..
content.html: yeah I looked into this a while back. The only way I could think of for avoiding symbol collisions is to unload one engine first before loading the next one. However, my attempts of using ign-plugin’s ForgetLibrary* functions to unload a plugin have been unsuccessful. It’s also mentioned in the function’s description that the unload operation is not guaranteed to succeed. I remember asking @Michael Grey about this before. So I’m out of ideas..

content.raw: good catch, fixed. [3e11405](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/commits/3e114056bf527107544bb93cfe140ce9fc61cd1b)
content.html: good catch, fixed. 3e11405

update.description:
~~Depends on pull request #200 and pull request #201. Please review them first~~

Adds ogre1.x and ogre2.x implementation of a thermal camera.

The data output is an image of single channel 16 bit temperature values. Typical thermal sensors produces data in 10mK or 100mK resolutions and this behavior can be configured by setting the thermal camera’s LinearResolution.

e.g. for LinearResolution of 0.01 \(10mK\), the max temperature data generated is:

65535 \* 0.01 = 655.35 Kelvin / 680.72 F / 360.4 C

Another example is the FLIR Lepton camera which outputs 14 bit data, which can be simulated by setting LinearResolution to 0.04.

The temperature of a Visual can be set using `Visual::SetUserData` function introduced in pull request #200 with the key `temperature`, and the environment temperature is set using `TheramlCamera::SetAmbientTemperature`

‌

Update [70b4a9b](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/commits/70b4a9b65a06fed9e64e2a7bffcc360192a31897): Added function to set temperature variation for heat sources \(instead of using a hard coded value\).  If not set, uniform temperature is assumed for the entire body of the heat source.
update.title: Add ThermalCamera

content.raw: LGTM. My remaining comments are not blockers.
content.html: LGTM. My remaining comments are not blockers.

content.raw: Just a small detail, for a cold scene where `min == max`, we end up with a division by zero here
content.html: Just a small detail, for a cold scene where min == max, we end up with a division by zero here

content.raw:
Adding `ogre` alongside `ogre2` here causes a crash:

`thermal_camera: /build/ogre-1.9-B6QkmW/ogre-1.9-1.9.0+dfsg1/OgreMain/include/OgreSingleton.h:80: Ogre::Singleton<T>::Singleton() [with T = Ogre::LogManager]: Assertion !msSingleton' failed.`

It's unrelated to this PR, but I'm wondering if you've looked into this @{557058:10b01d41-a2e9-4a41-a907-e6e2f03b6cd5} ? I've been having a similar problem on `ign-gazebo` trying to unload a scene to load a new one. It would be nice to prevent these 2 singletons from colliding.
content.html:
Adding ogre alongside ogre2 here causes a crash:

thermal_camera: /build/ogre-1.9-B6QkmW/ogre-1.9-1.9.0+dfsg1/OgreMain/include/OgreSingleton.h:80: Ogre::Singleton<T>::Singleton() [with T = Ogre::LogManager]: Assertion !msSingleton' failed.

It's unrelated to this PR, but I'm wondering if you've looked into this @Ian Chen ? I've been having a similar problem on ign-gazebo trying to unload a scene to load a new one. It would be nice to prevent these 2 singletons from colliding.

content.html: All these properties have public setters and getters, could they be private instead of protected?

content.raw: Regarding more uniform, do you mean same color throughout the object, i.e. flat shaded? The shaders output temperature and I convert them to gray scale in the [sample demo](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/src/1801393715437fa7fcfdbd430a5117271ce9d313/examples/thermal_camera/GlutWindow.cc#lines-89). There are very slight variations in the temperature readings for each object \(as a function of depth\).
content.html: Regarding more uniform, do you mean same color throughout the object, i.e. flat shaded? The shaders output temperature and I convert them to gray scale in the sample demo. There are very slight variations in the temperature readings for each object (as a function of depth).

content.raw: I would anticipate that the cube and sphere would be more uniform in this example.  Is this because it’s using “lighting” shaders in OpenGL/Ogre?
content.html: I would anticipate that the cube and sphere would be more uniform in this example. Is this because it’s using “lighting” shaders in OpenGL/Ogre?

content.raw: I'm wondering if you considered using `ignition::math::Temperature`. I think the advantage is making the unit clear. And once [this](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/issues/45/use-literals-with-temperature) is addressed we could do things like `SetAmbientTemperature(30_C)`. Just a suggestion...
content.html: I'm wondering if you considered using ignition::math::Temperature. I think the advantage is making the unit clear. And once this is addressed we could do things like SetAmbientTemperature(30_C). Just a suggestion...
